posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
Hi Everyone, I already know what you all will say - “BUY BEARING BLOCKS!” - but given the opportunity I would like to just drill the correct size, which would be a press fit of 1.1245". We don’t have access to a CNC that could cut them to the right size or have the funds to custom order every part. I am not aware of where we would purchase the right size other than a custom drill bit manufacturer. Previously we have used a 1.125" drill and just used a retaining compound to keep the bearings in place. It worked fine but took extra time. We would like to just buy the right size of 1.1245" but looking at the specifics of the order sheet shown below, I’m not aware of exactly what we would want for number of flutes and everything. image 1044×565 52 KB

image 1044×565 52 KB

image 1044×565 52 KB

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
I think you want a 1.1245" reamer.  If you can get one with a 1/2" shank to fit into most drill chuck on a drill press, life would be easier.

You’ll still need to drill a hole ~1.115 before reaming.  That pilot hole size for the reamer will sorta depend on how accurate and consistent you can drill the hole.

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
Sorry.  Do you have a drill press?  With a 1/2" capacity drill chuck?

Do you have a milling machine?  If so, you can bore the bearing hole with a boring head.  Not too difficult to set up and you’ll have great repeatability and accuracy.  However, it will likely take you longer overall versus the drill and reamer method for a gain that’s likely not worth it in the FRC context.

If you special order a drill (not a reamer), you’ll unlikely be able to drill it to the size you ordered even with multiple pilot holes leading up to the 1.1245".  It will still probably be a little oversize and you may still need retaining compound. You might be able to drill it on size if you had a rigid set up like a milling machine or a very large drill press and held the part well.  Your run-of-the-mill (no pun intended) drill press won’t be rigid enough.

If you order the custom drill, ensure the length is as short (rigid) as you can get away with.  i.e. if you typically drill 1/4" plates for bearings, order the drill bit an inch or so long.  Add on the shank length.   That’ll give you some wiggle room for thicker parts and sharpening.

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: We have had great success using a step bit instead of a hole bit. The hole bit isn’t sturdy enough and moves around when drilling it and causing the hole to be bigger. Get a step bit with the largest size as 1.125 and it will make (almost) perfect bearing holes. You can use a deburring tool to get it to fit perfectly.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: We have two vertical mills with what collets or supporting equipment idk

posts.name: hpeyerl
posts.cooked:
We bought an annular cutter that students put in the drill press. Perfect holes, everytime. Bearings need a light push on the arbor press.

Edit: perhaps it’s not an annular cutter. But it looks like this: https://www.homedepot.com/p/Milwaukee-1-1-4-in-Carbide-Hole-Cutter-1-Pack-49-57-8619/316866682

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Would this be able to cut all the way through a 2x1?

posts.name: Skuke (aka: Payton)
posts.cooked:
Technologyman00:

We have two vertical mills with what collets or supporting equipment idk

A full size knee mill with a R8 collet can hold up to a 7/8" shank.  …there are adapters to hold bigger cutters, but you might sacrifice rigidity and/or accuracy.  If your milling machine is smaller than a typical Bridgeport knee mill, then you’ll need to determine what shank your maximum size collet can hold.

Either way, you’ll fight the job less if you can make the setup rigid.  Shortest drill bit/reamer that you can buy and hold the part securely in a vise or clamped to the table.  …don’t forget to put a sacrificial board under the part if clamping on the mill table.  You don’t want to drill/ream into the table.  …don’t want to drill into the vise either .  ;-p

posts.name: hpeyerl
posts.cooked: Yup. We use it like that all the time.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
The linked one doesn’t look like it, but another annular cutter might.

Step drills and drill bits tend to drill oversize even if you go up in small increments. This is fine if you loctite the bearing in or use a rivet /screw to hold it in after assembly, otherwise it will vibrate and widen/loosen the hole over time. Of the two, a 1.06" drill followed by a 1.125" reamer or drill bit works well.

I own a couple of this reamer, and have turned down the shank on the lathe: https://www.wttool.com/fractional-straight-flute-chucking-reamers-19293

Annular cutters will work well without needing a shank turning down but might cost more.

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked:
We just got an annular cutter recently, cheap one ($25) from Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B074Z5HGG5?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details

Works great!

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Am I correct in thinking you use this in a mill? The 3/4" shank would not fit most drill presses.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked:
Pretty much any drill (twist, annular, step…) is going to drill a little out-of-round and at least a little oversize. That’s why reamers exist. If you really want a few tenths tolerance, you’re going to need to drill (a few thou under) and then ream.

Vex sells a 126 reamer, but if you really want 1245 for a press fit, you’ll either need to find/commission a suitable reamer, or get an adjustable one and take the time to dial it in.

link_counts.title: 1.126" Carbide Tipped Chucking Reamer - VEX Robotics

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked:
I second the Annular Cutter/ Annular Drill if you don’t have a CNC router.  You do need a big enough tool for the job but they cut really quickly and form holes that are quite round.

Depending on the tool you buy, you could be able to cut through two parallel planes that are 1-2" apart (Versa tube)

They also tolerate a much larger speed range than traditional drills and reamers.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Technologyman00:

We have two vertical mills with what collets or supporting equipment idk

McMaster-Carr or similar. Get the R8 shank and you don’t need a collet, straight shank make sure you’ve got the right collet.

Fit with a boring bar. Dial in to the diameter you need. Lock it down, with tape as needed. Pilot with a step drill.

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked:
Sure, this would be appropriate for a mill.

Does anyone know the Vex bearing OD tolerances? McMaster bearings with the same order magnitude cost are +/- 0.002".

posts.name: Sam Knight
posts.cooked: If your drill press has a common morse taper chuck (there are multiple sizes), that can be popped out and replaced with a weldon shank like this: https://www.amazon.com/Toolly-Industrial-Annular-Cutter-Drill-Use/dp/B08FCDGNVJ The weldon shank then accepts the annular cutter.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I’ve seen the Vex reamer chip teeth really easily, so I’d stick to an HSS reamer like the one I linked.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Thank you everyone! We will likely go with a custom reamer with supporting drill
